div1.p: Consulate of the United States of America at St. Paul de Loanda S.W.C. Africa
L. de R. du Verge to State Department Washington D.C.
Encloses Reasons why agents were appointed at Ambriz. Benguella & particularly Mossamedes.
United States Consulate St Paul de Loanda December 14th 1882
Hon: Wm. Hunter Asst. Sectry of State. Washington D.C.

Sir I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your desparch No 10, in regard to Agents appointed by me until approved by the Hon: Sectry of State; it was and still is with the intention of promoting Am: Commerce in this part of the world, beside putting a stop to run away seaman, for abuse received on board Am: whalers, and while enforcing the U.S. law over this jurisdiction, to give prompt justice to seamen, masters or officers. "Mossamedes" will in a few years become important large fields of wheat, corn, sugar cane, and cotton are now in cultivation.

The Portuguese Govt. is organizing small colonies all over that district, The Boers in "Whilloh" and "Humpata" are cutting conformity with the Portuguese a route from the interior; so that their crops, and the result of their bounty such as Hides, Ivory & Ostrich Feathers, can be carried to Mossamedes: these colonies as well as the Boers;- and even the natives of the interior who seem to follow now the
example of the Boers will soon want Farming to; and I do not know if any to be compared with those of the U.S. for simplicity, denability and cheapness. The merchants and large land bulders will need also steam mills, and other machinery for making Rum, Sugar, grinding corn and wheats, cleaning and pressing cotton &a&a Am: Whalers seem to make their head quarters now at the place, although the best have been grand to them by the Portuguese govt. at Loanda.

To understand that nine Whalers were there during the last two months. From the "Eliza Adams" three seamen ran away, and from the " Alice Knowles" a man was discharged by reason of sickness; these seamen have been sent to me from Mossamedes at a great expense, and I find myself compelled to keep them until I am able to forward them to Santiago "Cape de Verde" by mail steamers which only takes them occasionally, more as a favor, although I pay to the Capt. pound symbol 5.0.0, for each man.

Mr. J. L. Povres that I appointed until approved by the Hon: Sectry of State is the largest merchant of Mossamedes, a young
man, full of energy, and ambitions to promote the commerce and developent of Mossamedes.

It is only upon close inquiry, as to be; capacity, intergrity, capability &a&a that I appointed him. If the state Dept has any objections to these appointments, I will nofify them at once as not having been accepted by the state Dept. I have never seen either of the gentlemen at Ambriz, Benguella & Mossamedes; but I am confident that an agent is needed at Mossamedes for the interest of Am: Commerce and protection of Am: Seamen and others visiting that port.
I have the honor to be Sir Your obedient servant L de R. du Verge
